PDB can enable many more interesting features. With community support, it can quickly fix some severe bugs and implement stronger anti-cheat measures (such as X-ray vision and item duplication prevention). Deleting PDB is not beneficial for the BDS community; it can be said to hinder the development of BDS. As an ordinary server owner, I am already preparing to switch to Geyser to support Bedrock Edition players. If PDB must be removed, I believe the number of BDS users will decrease. Additionally, there may be many vulnerabilities (0day) that will no longer be reported, at least not to the official channels.

I don't understand how Microsoft expects the Bedrock multiplayer experience to be even remotely comparable to that of Java Edition without providing this kind of information. Removing the PDB from BDS is going to make it extremely difficult, or even impossible for the multiplayer experience to truly flourish as it has on Java Edition.

Due to the significant role that PDB file plays in BDS plugin development, removing PDB files from the BDS community has no benefit from any point of view, no matter players or developers.
If the PDB file is removed on 1.21 and after, there would be no good that in both sides regardless devs and players because of the lack of information. It would make Bedrock Editions more likely to become a substitute for Java Editions, and additionally, no vulnerability or any security issues would be reported from players community.

As a JE/BE pluggin developer or a player playing Minecraft for over 10 years, I gently wish that Mojang/Microsoft could consider providing a fully supported debugging and maintenance environment, though might be a security risk, we are understandably concerned about it and believe that there would be a solution for each side in the whole MCPE community.
Minecraft is an open, creative, and always entertaining sandbox game. Please don‚Äôt take away the heart of creativity from us.

Mojang and Microsoft, what are you doing?

As the post above describes, in the preview version of Bedrock Edition's server pack for 1.21.10, all PDB files have been removed in opposite of the communities long ongoing request for full PDB files. This change was silenced and not mentioned in any of the versions patch/release notes. Myself and many others are not sure if you (Microsoft/Mojang) are aware of how drastic and severe the actions you are taking regarding "fixing bugs" and "stopping exploits" is when you remove PDB files. The impact for standalone Bedrock servers (those who are not in a partnership program with Microsoft/Mojang) and community made modifications for the game (excluding exploits) is severe. A large majority of server plugin creators use the PDB files to fix bugs and prevent exploits in their plugins to allow standalone servers to have a better experience without requiring a large team to handle each individual problem. Many "mod" creators are also drastically affected by this change due to not having access to the officially supported and developed Bedrock Edition protocol documentation (as of right now). Projects such as BDSX, LeviLamina and Amethyst (BDSX and LeviLamina being around for years while Amethyst being relatively new) have either been cancelled or have ended support for future versions.

Mojang and Microsoft, we as a community beg of you to revert this change and allow the developers of the Bedrock Edition community to develop once again.

Let's be honest - no documentation effort will ever replace good old PBDs. You want to improve security by hiding things - this doesn't work, threat actor are very often good at disassembly. You're mostly shooting the foot of modders which are helpful in patching security vulnerabilities, since they want to play without cheaters. Reconsider your course of action.

cybersecurity specialist here. I understand the surface level security reasons for removing pdb's from distribution. Its the default with microsoft for a good reason, it helps with securing the application against exploits and protects the Intellectual property that is the code. however, it cannot be ignored that the reason these PDB files were included in the first place was to allow the community to attempt to keep up with the rising tide that is hacking and to keep developers from having to do treadmill work every time a new exploit is found. 

a modding api is not a valid solution in this case, as you would potentially have to document every subroutine and add hooks to thousands of lines of code. minecraft has kept its modding community so active for so long because observing the behavior of both java and bedrock has been simple enough that inexperienced coders can attempt game design. obfuscating will just increase the treadmill work for devs more then it currently is, turn away server admins and server developers, and kill off what has made bedrock worth what it is to Mojang. 

I implore you to continue distributing PDB files with the server, while this move is practical on paper it has too many problems in this current situation to justify the action.

It cannot be overstated how critical this is file is for Bedrock modding as a whole. If this is intentional then I am incredibly disappointed in Mojang for even considering this, but am hopeful that this is nothing more than a mistake. Removal of the PDB files would instantly and single-handedly kill the vast majority of large bedrock server networks. Aside from driving more sales of the game, server networks tend to be some of the leading contributors to the bedrock marketplace, which means their closure would result in a significant and direct net loss in profit for Mojang. These already require a team of full time staff to maintain, and dropping something like this would make the amount of work required to upkeep a server orders of magnitude more difficult and costly, and thus unsustainable.

I believe wholeheartedly that it's in Mojang's best interest that the PDB files continue be provided for a number of reasons. Considering all that's going on with Minecraft lately in terms of exploits, taking debug symbols away could likely result in less awareness of reporting or dealing with exploits and result in anything malicious communities discover to stay in effect far longer. On the other side of things, sever hosting will become much more difficult for dedicated servers. There's also the fact that it would harm the creativity of the addon scene, which is really hitting it's stride lately in bedrock edition. Please reconsider.

Java player sending their support. As a Java player I enjoy modding the game. Mods like Blue Skies, Better Nether, The Aether, Applied Energistics 2 and many, many more provide fun content for the game when I get tired of the base game. Mods for older versions of minecraft such as Cypress and Reindev have been some of the most fun I've had with the game in a long time. I cannot imagine minecraft without mods, and I understand that Java is not always an option for all players. If you take away the PDB file,  you alienate a huge portion of the community, and take away that feeling of freedom and creativity that minecraft is known for. There is no one correct way to play minecraft, and that includes whether you play vanilla or modded. By taking away the ability to create mods, Mojang goes against their long-standing motto of "We don't want to tell the player how they should play the game"

English (translated by Google Translate):

Please Mojang pay attention to this community petition feedback!

The deletion of the Program Database (PDB) file makes server debugging and development more difficult, or even impossible.

Of course, those hacker programs and cheating clients will not be affected by this, because they use signature addressing instead of PDB.

And, I don‚Äôt know if your studio or company knows that the cooperative service provider is not using BDS, but its own server?

In addition, deleting the PDB file will only cause the anti-cheating and anti-attack system of Bedrock Dedicated Servers (BDS) to completely collapse. Unless your studio or company is able to ensure that BDS does not have any easily exploitable vulnerabilities, community players will give priority to Java or GeyserMC, which has poor performance, when choosing the Minecraft server.

At the same time, I hope that Minecraft, as a game started by Notch and originated from the community, can return to the community. Therefore, I once again implore Mojang to pay attention to this community petition feedback!

Dear Mojang Team,

I am writing to express my concern regarding the recent removal of a crucial file from the Bedrock Server without prior communication. This decision has had a significant impact on the community, which relies heavily on this file.

Previously, you assured us that you would prioritize community engagement and communication. However, this action contradicts those assurances, especially after recent efforts to rebuild trust following negative feedback about game updates and broken promises.

Removing such an important file without informing the community has understandably led to a resurgence of negative comments. In this instance, these comments seem justified. 

If you plan to remove the PDB file, I strongly recommend updating the reference documentation(if u can even call it that) accordingly to support those affected by this change.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
On behalf of the Minecraft Community,

The decision to remove PDB files in the latest version has significant controversy, Im very opposed to this decision.The removal of these files will severely impact the modding community, anticheat systems on public servers, and overall creativity within Minecraft
Modding has always been a cornerstone of the Minecraft community, allowing players to customize and enhance their gaming experience. Removing PDB files makes modding nearly impossible, stripping players of the tools they need to create and share innovations. Creating mods becomes very challenging, if not impossible.This decision stifles the creative contributions of the community, which have played a vital role in keeping the game vibrant and engaging.
Another critical concern is the impact on anti-cheat systems used in public servers. These systems often rely on PDB files to function correctly
The removal of PDB files in the latest version of Minecraft:Bedrock Edition NEEDS reconsideration. The negative impact on the modding community, anti-cheat systems, and overall creativity within the game cannot be overstated. As a passionate member of the Minecraft, I urge developers to recognize the value these files bring to the game and to reconsider their removal. Preserving the ability to mod the game is essential for maintaining the vibrant, creative, and fair environment that has made Minecraft the beloved game it is today.

Simply saying "just make everything async" is just wrong, that's not how games work.

While yes, chunk loading and generation - and especially saving - should definitely be improved (and moved off the main thread?), per-dimension ticking may have a loooot of unforseen consequences, especially with the plugin frameworks, such as Spigot/Paper and its events, not to mention A LOT of other concurrency issues and workarounds that would make such a process even worse.

The rest of that list is also plain and simple wrong (5.: lighting has already been greatly improved in 1.14 and doesn't really put any strain on the server anymore, 6.: no two entities will have the same exact path to find, unless they are in the same exact position and have the same exact data and goals, 7.: no).

A similar block-building Java-based game, Avorion, uses multi-threading for their servers. Usually you got "worker threads" to handle the AI, "generator threads" to generate the world, and "script background threads" which is whats in the name. And in Minecraft's case, they could have dedicated "garbage collection" threads too, or combine that into the script background threads.

Just a note on this: 1.14.4 already made lighting, world generation and chunk loading async (separate thread). It comes at the cost of making it slower when there is a single thread due to extra overhead of making sure it works correctly.

Per dimension thread seem feasible but ultimately shouldn't be necessary.

Chunk gzipping and saving used to be separate thread in 1.12.2 but that got removed due to the possibility of duplication exploits it caused.

No idea what mob AI is suggested here. Making it multi threaded - I think moving mob AI to separate thread could be viable.

Packet handling - this is a hard one. It's also not much of an issue on servers afaik. Actual packet deserialization is already in netty thread and servers generally don't receive huge packets that need a lot of processing.

Overall a big part of performance drop here is small things adding up (which is not an easy fix) but will hopefully be fixed once and for all when project valhalla (https://openjdk.java.net/projects/valhalla/) is done. This will be a major performance boost but there is nothing mojang can do make it come earlier. It's been in development since 2014.

The other big issue is chunk saving on main thread which shouldn't be too hard to patch out in a mod, forge, spigot or any other project but it could come at the cost of adding hard to predict and fix exploits. There isn't really much public information about them (for obvious reasons) so I can't know for sure.

This suggestion is very needed, for Minecraft itself too, not just serverside, but also the game itself. This option would allow us to be able to have more smooth experience playing large worlds in the game, where constant lighting and redstone updates are needed. This allows Mojang to expand on the possiblites of Minecraft without worrying about lag.

As it currently stands, we no longer live in a world where game devs can be lazy and only use one core; those days ended more than a few years ago. Processors aren't scaling up in per-core performance as much as they used to, they're getting more cores instead. The fact that some servers have faced increasing problems because Minecraft still only runs one logic thread for several years now is unacceptable; this is even an issue in the modding sphere now, as I ran a game on 1.15 with a fairly restrained modlist... and came out with sub-30 framerates on a machine that can run almost anything the industry can throw at it. I have no doubts 1.16 would run even worse with mods.

Beyond all that, though, I've also observed poor performance on my private server I run for my friends, and have had constant lag problems despite running on good hardware and with only a handful of people. That's... depressing. And though I haven't had much time to test, I suspect the only reason the server hasn't started running even worse with the move from 1.14 to 1.16 is because I also moved from Spigot to Paper in the process.

This needs to happen. There's no excuse. It doesn't have to happen all at once, though. Start with threading dimensions separately, that should be a fairly easy starting point. 1.17 for the first steps, no later.

2. Chunk loading
On 2b2t, there used to be a plugin that refuses to load chunks when the player attempting to load the chunks are moving too fast. Hausemaster eventually banned elytras on 2b2t, so there is no need for the plugin anymore, but just imagine how much would server TPS for servers with people traveling really fast improve with this.

3. Chunk caching
Chunks that are frequently visited by members of a server, such as chunks containing a base or chunks for the Cowmercial district on Hermitcraft should be prioritized when loading chunks, and should also be stored in RAM or some other alternative storage for fast access. I mean, having chunks for a build load faster than other places is really great, and also reduces stress on the SSD/hard drive.

I truly believe optimizing Minecraft for multi-core handling is going to be a game changer for everyone in the community. having the complete PDB (Player Database) for your Minecraft Bedrock Dedicated Server can be crucial for a variety of reasons:

  1. Player Management: With the complete PDB, you have comprehensive control over player management. You can efficiently monitor, track, and manage player activities, including bans, permissions, and activity logs.

  2. Server Security: Access to the complete PDB enables you to bolster the security of your server. You can identify suspicious activities, track potential threats, and take necessary actions to protect your server and its community.

  3. Data Analysis: The PDB contains valuable data that can be analyzed to gain insights into player behavior, preferences, and trends. This information can be used to optimize server performance, tailor gameplay experiences, and enhance community engagement.

  4. Community Moderation: By having access to the complete PDB, you empower your moderation team to enforce server rules effectively. They can identify problematic players, address rule violations promptly, and foster a positive and inclusive community environment.

  5. Customization and Development: For server administrators and developers, the complete PDB serves as a valuable resource for customization and development purposes. It provides essential data for creating custom plugins, mods, and gameplay features tailored to the unique needs of your server.

It is essential for player management, security, moderation, analysis, and customization in a thriving community.

Before we think about why Microsoft is removing PDB, it's worth thinking about why Microsoft acquired Mojang. It's clear that this is an investment, and Microsoft wants to make a profit with Minecraft. As a result, Bedrock Edition came into being, unifying all editions except Java Edition, and introducing a marketplace that attempts to monopolize the way to access extended content outside of Java. But it's clear that the market is a failure, and I believe that more than 95% of Minecraft players have never spent money on the market. As a result, Microsoft began to gradually test and cut down the effects that can be achieved outside the market, with the aim of forcing players to use the market and creators to join the market. So the purpose of removing the PDB is self-evident.

Title: A Call for Microsoft to Restore PDB Files for Minecraft Bedrock Edition Servers
Introduction
With the advancement of technology and the evolution of gaming communities, players' expectations for gaming experiences have grown. Particularly in the realm of multiplayer online games, Minecraft stands out as a globally popular game where the development of plugins for the Bedrock Edition is crucial for enhancing user experience. However, Microsoft's recent decision to remove Program Database (PDB) files from Bedrock Edition servers has sparked extensive discussions and controversies. This essay aims to explore the significance of PDB files and urges Microsoft to reconsider its decision to foster healthier community development.

The Importance of PDB Files
Program Database (PDB) files are critical carriers of debugging information that play an essential role in software development. Whether it's .NET projects or native C++ applications, PDB files contain function addresses, variable names, and source code line numbers, enabling developers to effectively perform breakpoint debugging, trace error sources, and optimize performance 1. Furthermore, PDB files support profiling tools, which help identify bottlenecks in complex systems such as Minecraft servers.

In the context of Minecraft Bedrock Edition servers, PDB files are equally indispensable. They not only assist developers in quickly identifying and resolving runtime issues but also ensure compatibility across different versions through symbol indexing mechanisms. This is particularly important for maintaining an active and continuously growing user base. Especially for players who rely on specific plugin functionalities to enhance their gaming experience, the lack of effective debugging support could lead to malfunctioning plugins, thereby impacting overall game quality.

Community Feedback and Concerns
Since Microsoft announced its plan to remove PDB files, many developers have expressed strong opposition. They fear that this move will significantly affect the functionality and subsequent maintenance of third-party plugins. For instance, well-known plugin loaders like LeviLamina face significant challenges due to the absence of necessary symbol information 13. This not only limits innovation but also weakens the ecosystem's technical competitiveness.

Moreover, from a long-term perspective, the lack of PDB file support might lead to more unforeseen problems, such as hard-to-reproduce crashes or performance degradation. If these issues cannot be promptly addressed, they could harm players' trust in the game, reducing engagement. Therefore, maintaining PDB files is crucial for ensuring the health and stability of the gaming ecosystem.

Microsoft‚Äôs Stance and Considerations
Despite these concerns, we understand that Microsoft may have reasonable justifications behind this decision. On one hand, considering security and intellectual property protection, publicly disclosing detailed debugging information poses potential risks. On the other hand, simplifying deployment processes and reducing maintenance burdens reflect corporate efficiency pursuits 2. However, whether this approach truly serves the best interests remains debatable.

In fact, with appropriate permission controls and technological measures, it is possible to meet both security requirements and retain the value of PDB files. For example, encrypted transmission methods can be used to distribute PDB files, authorizing access only to verified developers. Alternatively, establishing officially recognized third-party platforms allows developers to obtain necessary resources while adhering to relevant agreements. This way, information security can be ensured while fostering innovation.

Conclusion and Recommendations
In summary, although Microsoft may have various considerations for deciding to remove PDB files, restoring them appears especially necessary to promote the prosperity of the Minecraft Bedrock Edition server ecosystem. Hence, we propose the following recommendations:

Restart PDB File Distribution: Suggest that Microsoft reassess its current policy to allow eligible developers access to PDB files.
Enhance Security Management Measures: Implement stringent access control strategies to ensure that only legitimate users can access sensitive materials.
Build Collaborative Frameworks: Establish closer cooperation with the community to jointly develop rules beneficial to both parties.
Ultimately, restoring PDB files does not only provide more convenience for developers but also further stimulates community vitality, pushing Minecraft towards higher levels. It is hoped that Microsoft will listen to the voices of players and developers alike, taking proactive actions to address everyone's needs.

I'm sorry to say this but Minecraft Realms feels like a scam, and i'm pretty disgusted that they think this is even remotely acceptable.

Part 1:

I played Minecraft starting around 2011 and went through a lot with this game. I took a long break, but have recently returned to the game with a few friends. Two of my friends have the game on Switch and I have always had it on PC. We started playing where I hosted a world and it was great fun, but my friends couldn't play unless I was online and hosting the game. Due to when I bought Minecraft, I was granted a copy of the Windows 10 edition which is what I've been using in order to play with my friends on the Switch.

Last night, I started the Realms free trial and was quickly disappointed with the render distance. The world we spawned in was a big ocean world with a bunch of little islands. Before connecting the world to realms, I could see islands in the distance, a large ice biome over the ocean and lots of interesting things underwater. After uploading to the Realm, all I can see is the sun setting underwater. Playing before uploading to realms I had the ability to take a boat to an island I saw in the distance. Upon arriving, I was able to look around and spot a village to the South, along with another village beyond that once arriving. After uploading to Realms, I am unable to see these landmarks from the same distance.

Continued...

Part 2:

After looking up how to increase the render distance, I found that it was impossible to do so in Realms, which is why I am here now, submitting feedback to fix this issue. Support has come out to say that the render distance is "working as intended" but if that's intended, they are essentially saying they intend for the game to be broken. Per the exploring example above, the low render distance negatively affects gameplay. Players cannot efficiently explore the world without being able to see past a couple hundred blocks. I've read some of the other posts here where the low render distance prevents the game from loading blocks at a certain distance and has broken a players' sorting machine. There are also players that can't even see their friends' houses due to the limitations and quitting realms.

I am playing on a powerful PC, with the ability to set the render distance up to 80 chunks. Players should be able to control their own render distance depending on the device limitations. A Switch would be less powerful than my PC, so each should have their own control. Similar to playing before realms, I should be able to see at a decent distance in order to play the game as intended, reaching back to 2011, or 2014 when players could see at a decent distance and play the game as intended.

Continued...

Part 3:

Render distance is a pretty substantial part of the Minecraft experience. Going back to 2011 when I was just starting out, you could easily get lost if you couldn't navigate via landmarks in the landscape. Render distance allowed the player to see larger creations, or the "craft" part of Minecraft. As mentioned above, render distance affects exploration in a big way. Before uploading to realms, I was able to seek out villages, but after Realms, could not see these landmarks at the same distance. I had to row out into the ocean to see the first ice island and once I got to that point, I couldn't even see my home island anymore. It's terrible for navigation and a broken mechanic. "Working as intended" is simply broken.

As a result of this, I am having second thoughts about keeping the Realms service. We will feel out the free trial and go from there. Paying $8 a month for a lesser experience than playing for free doesn't make any sense. The only benefit is the always on mechanic where anyone can get on without the host, but does it make more sense for me to just keep my game running at home if one of my friends wants to play that day?

Continued...

Part 4:

As much as I'd like to keep a Realm for that always on mechanic, the render distance is a broken mechanic, not working as intended. No matter how many times you say it's working as intended, I don't believe the low render distance is intended because otherwise the base game would have that same low render distance. If this issue gets resolved, I will consider retaining a subscription to realms, but paying for a lesser experience does not make any sense.

End (Why did this get put at the top?)

I'm sorry you all have NO idea what your actually asking for here...     I run a Java Server myself for a small gaming community and the max we can set our server is up to 11 chunks without getting rather insane server lag!!       We've tested up to 16 chunks and the game becomes unplayable due to the lag.    12 chunks is about the limit but it becomes very laggy if we have more than 5-6 players online.

 

The default of 10 chunks is loading 10 chunks from the player in every direction.    So each player loads up a square of 21 by 21 chucks, which comes out to 21x21 = 441 chunks per player.   So a typical 8 player server would have 3,528 chunks loaded for 8 players online at the same time.    So the server has to keep track of basically everything that is going on in the 3,528 chunks all the entities, enemies, players, generate new terrain, etc...       

Now if you increase it to 11 chunk view distance, it's loading a 23x23 square for each player.   Or a total of 529 chunks per player.    Or 4,232 chunks total for 8 players on the server.

If you step that up to 16 chunk view distance, it's loading a 33x33 square for each player.   A total of 1,089 chunks per player.   For those 8 players it would be 8,712 chunks loaded on the server at the same time.

 

I think you can see where this is going....

Minecraft Bedrock servers should be designed to run on ARM CPUs to expand accessibility and efficiency. ARM architecture offers lower power consumption and cost-effectiveness compared to traditional x86 CPUs, making it ideal for a broader range of server setups, including small-scale deployments and energy-efficient data centers. By supporting ARM CPUs, Minecraft Bedrock servers can reach a wider audience, including users with ARM-based devices such as a Raspberry Pi. This encourages more diverse server hosting options and promotes innovation within the Minecraft community. Additionally, ARM-based servers can contribute to sustainability efforts by reducing energy consumption and carbon footprint, aligning with the growing emphasis on eco-friendly computing solutions.

So i've been having issues with the language filter hashingout entire commands in my command blocks.

Language filter needs to be a gamerule on boolean.

HOWEVER!! I found a work around.
The filter is targeting the name spaces and tag spaces for your targets. So things like @e[type=piglin,name=CC] is NOT acceptable. So add quotes like so below

@e[type=piglin,name="CC"]

Even though the quotes are intended for when there are spaces in the name space. It solidifies and isolates it to keep the system from getting confused.

Let me know if this helps you.

READ THIS COMMENT IF YOU ARE HAVING THIS PROBLEM. I FOUND A WAY. I had this same problem with typing commands into my realm, but there is a way to get around it. Regular commands typed into the chat will work, but command blocks and signs will be censored. In a personal world that is NOT a realm, it will not sensor these things. So what you need to do is download your realm, go into the downloaded world, and type in whatever you want to type into a command block or sign etc. Then you re-upload that world and the sign or command block will not be censored. Pre-existing signs and commands that are uploaded to a realm will not be censored. This is a kind of long and annoying process, but it has been very useful for me.

if it really bothers you u can edit the file in the game called profanity_filter.wlist and is found

C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\Microsoft.MinecraftUWP_1.16.22002.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe\data\profanity_filter.wlist

you change it to .txt and just delete the words from the file u want to be removed, just remember to change it back to .wlist

A solution I've found is to just delete the profanity list which is in fact client-side, however you do need a rooted phone for this, as it requires the modification of the base.apk file
1st step is to go into your phone's root directory with your chosen file explorer (in my case, total commander) and you'll need to navigate to the /data/app/com.mojang.minecraftpe folder and extract the base.apk file to any of your normally accessible folders
2nd step is renaming the base.apk file to base.zip so you can open and edit its contents

for the 3rd step you must open the assets folder within the zip file and find a file called "profanity_filter.wlist"  and just straight up delete it
you can now rename the zip file back to "base.apk" and overwrite the one that's in the root folder with it
